el4gF6KRUDzamnxmN0Kvyw.text: The three of us had an early dinner. Two of us ordered the fish and chips.  I believe this is the best fish and chips I have ever had.  I'm not sure what was in the breading but it was delicious.  Even the ketchup was amazing.  I have to come back again before I leave.

photos.caption: Photo of Bread Street Kitchen - Singapore, Singapore. The best fish and chips ever!

H_LC5-DVW8wWMD0CJRQ-0g.text: Sloppy service with poorly trained Wait staff doesn't help make us feel comfortable. Our starters were perfect except for the hefty price point. With marinated salmon, bream and tuna nice portion sizes although the wait staff dropped the remaining sauce into our niece's pocketbook with out realizing it. The waitress refilled our water glasses by serving across our plates instead of moving to the right of each guest. Our coffee was dishwasher quality and the espresso was lacking true flavor. When we didn't order dessert the waitress took a LONG time to present our check. The famous chef that owns this place should re-train the entire wait staff.

phnklyyWrKLNGJjTz7dYMw.text: cocktails and starters to kick off the fiancé's early birthday dinner. Alaskan king crab and apple cocktail and Sunday roast were the winners. Perfectly cooked and full of flavour. Wood oven king prawns were ok. Bang bang chicken salad was just more than mildly spicy, with plenty of the tender chicken. A bit too much as a main size, I would recommend the entree size if having a starter, especially because the bread and butter are so delicious. Good service, great bar staff, nice ambience

photos.caption: Photo of Bread Street Kitchen - Singapore, Singapore. King prawns and crab & apple cocktail
Photo of Bread Street Kitchen - Singapore, Singapore. Cocktails

yWUZNKZpwF_MvszzqMc8vQ.text: Had dinner here for the first time. Had scallops and beetroot pie as appetizers. These were excellent. Unfortunately it went downhill from there, starting with unmemorable risotto and greasy fish and chips. Pineapple carpaccio was alright, but the pavlova was a disaster. Soggy merangue, plus orange not properly peeled. Not worth the hype in my opinion. Service was not too bad.

v8JKlPXvrH2XlbHUBm2PGA.text: Prawn salad was amazing! You get 4 good size prawns and a nice little salad with it, the bread basket for the table was delicious and had good variety. I also got the butternut soup which tasted great and nice and creamy!My wife had the burger which was top quality even well done! The meat patty was excellent.

photos.caption: Photo of Bread Street Kitchen - Singapore, Singapore. Nice fitout!!!

fMyOeATfH_FvQOLfE3bR5g.text: A little disappointed. We came for the Sunday Roast but they told us they ran out (towards the end of our meal the table next to us got some). The duck with the pumpkin purée was excellent. The lamb shank had barely any meat and the dish ended up being a very expensive bowl of mash potatoes. The cannelloni was so so

gpaJ2dqppMFz6YxoBCKDFQ.text: For a restaurant named Bread Street the bread basket is just mehhh...Perhaps the biggest negative of the afternoon was how the host handled seating us all. Ultimately she's giving excuses vs offering solutions and came off non-responsive so we had to take initiative to make sure we get our seats. As though walking in without a reservation is unwelcomed. The host came off uppity but our waiter was efficient and friendly.Other negative was "no more" Beef Wellington. Wtfbbq! :\Food was just ok to great.Scallops- Great. Well cooked. Wish there was more than 3 though.Shepherds Pie- Deceivingly small. Lamb pieces were chunky but tender. Pretty ok dish.Black Cod- Simply delicious.Fish Cake- Skip. Picture looked tastier than it is. Much too dry.Beef Burger- Burger was normal. Nothing amazing. What's amazing is the ketchup for the fries. Surprisingly good.Overall make a reservation if you're a GR fan or curious, because if you had to wait, skip this place. Better joints around.

photos.caption: Photo of Bread Street Kitchen - Singapore, Singapore. Fish Cake. Dry. Skip!
Photo of Bread Street Kitchen - Singapore, Singapore. Deceivingly small.
Photo of Bread Street Kitchen - Singapore, Singapore. Wish there was more scallops. Yum!

0mk-5H2weSgkLgAS_ySJjg.text: Awesome food! Huge gluten free menu! The duck was perfectly cooked and they even had gluten free bread for the table. Service was attentive and even though we didn't have a reservation, we were still able to get seats in the bar area.

R42RkuCDFspnNoGqY7oq4A.text: Came her for lunch.  Had their lunch special -- 3 courses for $48. It's fairly popular for lunch, so make a reservation. Had the tuna carpaccio, quinoa salad, duck terrine, shepherd's pie, beef cheeks, cheese plate, and Bailey's creme brulee.  Nothing was astounding or mind-blowing, which is disappointing for a celebrity chef restaurant. the famous bread basket was pretty standard, although the sourdough roll was very good.I guess Gordon Ramsey gets famous for getting restaurants in order, but he's not really known for any his dishes, persay?

Stiik-8Ihvdm-S8Hc4TDXA.text: Go with no expectation that's I would say.Had the fish and chips and it's actually nice, the batter for the chips and the tartar sauce is nice. Also had their Sunday roast but I find it okay okay, meat was cooked nicely like the way we wanted. The potato that came as the side dish is nice too, soft and creamy inside but crispy outside. :)The California maki roll is  Cured meat is okay too but it definitely goes well with the Caesar salad that we ordered.But honestly I think they're quite heavy on their salt. Too generous, too generous

photos.caption: Photo of Bread Street Kitchen - Singapore, Singapore. Fish and chips
Photo of Bread Street Kitchen - Singapore, Singapore. Sunday roast
Photo of Bread Street Kitchen - Singapore, Singapore. Cold starter and salad

y2394xmJBmzC_qvmAWELcg.text: FANTASTIC food every time!!!, This time we got: Salmon ceviche, ruby grapefruit, mango, jalapeño, lime, coriander And Flatbread, butternut squash, Taleggio cheese, mushrooms, pine nuts, basil pestoAndSeared scallops, carrot purée,treacle cured bacon, apple, celery cress.For starters, so we sheared 3 starters 5 people. After that I got: Roasted duck breast, boulangère potatoes, cabbage purée and mulled berries sauce.For dessert I got: Coffee and white chocolate parfait with poached blackberries I have nothing else to say, everything was perfect. We sad outside becouse indside was all booked op, we sad directly in the evening sun witch af noce view to the lake, a lovely evening!but there is always busy, so book a table! Just to be sure

photos.caption: Photo of Bread Street Kitchen - Singapore, Singapore. Coffee and White chocolate parfait with poached blackberries
Photo of Bread Street Kitchen - Singapore, Singapore. So good!                                    Duck brast, cabbage puree and mulled berries sauce
Photo of Bread Street Kitchen - Singapore, Singapore. Salmon.                                       Flatbread.                                   Scallops.

zsWuizHzGWqOzF3PDBHWxQ.text: Great food, excellent service. Overall brilliant experience. But it comes with a nice price as well.We had the scallops, tuna tartare, and beef Wellington, all perfectly executed. If you add a cocktail,  desert and wine, you should reach the 200 SGD per person. A bit pricy, but seriously good, and with a great staff. Kudos to them, and kudos to the Chef..

photos.caption: Photo of Bread Street Kitchen - Singapore, Singapore. Chocolate and caramel lava cake.
Photo of Bread Street Kitchen - Singapore, Singapore. Beef Wellington
Photo of Bread Street Kitchen - Singapore, Singapore. Scallops

TiWzuz3aPW6nuI_UPPva5w.text: It pains me to give Bread Street Kitchen even one star - it deserves none. We went in on a Saturday morning, expecting to have a wonderful brunch. We left feeling grossly full and severely unsatisfied. First the bread basket. Perhaps stale is too strong a word, but most of the bread was exactly that. Dry, tasteless and hard. The butter was overly salted. I adjusted my expectations and hoped for a less disappointing rest of the meal. We all ordered the Eggs Benedict to play it safe - there's no way they'd get this wrong. Eggs: overly poached. Rubbery consistency. Ham: so so so salty. I needed a few glasses of water to wash this down. Hollandaise: Thick. Extremely salty. And thick.I felt like I was eating a tub of butter with old bread and a sad egg substitute. I didn't have it in me to order anything else- I wanted to leave as soon as I could. But the slow and pathetic service at the restaurant, didn't even allow for that. Perhaps filming a few episodes of 'Kitchen Nightmares' right here at BSK, will help Gordon Ramsay turn his restaurant around.

SBAoGYoXaV-CE0HHg0tASA.text: Service was standard.. As what you'd expect.. Didn't take long for the food to arrive and timing was good as what you'd see in hells kitchen or any other Gordon Ramsay shows... Mac and cheese.. Was FANTASTIC!! So flavourful and Mac was cooked nicely. Shepard's pie however was abit bland although the lamb and mash was fresh and smooth. Fish and chips? WOW! Highly reccomended!! Fresh and full of flavour! I'd come here again if I could!

photos.caption: Photo of Bread Street Kitchen - Singapore, Singapore

P59XsRTgfGh2A2IogroC5A.text: Visited this restaurant last year, a month after its grand opening. Came with a strong expectation, given that it was a Ramsay restaurant. Ordered a main course for myself, with an appetiser and a dessert to share for two. Conducted an extensive due dilligence to pick out the best dish to order before the visit.Appetiser: Roasted veal carpaccioThis was heavenly. Everything was well-seasoned and tender. Prior reviews got this one spot on; this was a gem.Main Course: Fish and Chips + BSK Short Rib burger (my friend's)My fish and chips was meh. The fish was of a great quality, but it was very under-seasoned. Mediocre. However, my friend remarked his burger as delicious, tender and juicy.Dessert: Monkey Shoulder CheesecakeMediocre. Ended the night with a flat note.Although my visit was alright, consistency seems to be an issue here. For example, my friend visited this restaurant again a few months after, and his friend's rib burger tasted like rubber. Many reviews online have been scathing as well regarding its food quality, and whether it is value for money. Worth a visit once, but you are probably better off spending your money elsewhere afterwards.

hSi6WgsetksUQ6RqTFIKQg.text: Overrated - definitely not worth the money.Food doesn't taste good.They make a mistake in order and all they say is "well, at least it's cheaper than what you wanted to get" - that's not the point. Whatever you brought by mistake didn't taste good.It's good to try it because of the name of the restaurant, but that's it. The only thing I would say is they use good ingredients.

Ip27d7IiRFHuHt7c73jsBA.text: Great drinks, kind staff (although not the most attentive), chill vibe and comfortable setting especially when they open the window doors when it's not hazy outside. Food is OK at best.Unfortunately I've never been a fan of Gordon Ramsey restaurants. From NYC to London to Las Vegas, his formal dining spots never served any dishes that I would tout at memorable. For the most part, this one isn't much different.Gotta admit, I love the vibe and most everything surrounding this place, especially how casual it is for a bustling Marina Bay Sands restaurant. The food is just nothing special. Went for the recommended fish and chips which I hoped would be crispy batter with tasty fish inside. Rather it was a soggy batter that tasted like any other fish and chips I've ever had except this felt much more full of oil. Tartare sauce and fries were nothing special. Not to mention we waited a very long time for this to come out.We also went for the tuna tartare which had a fishy taste to it surprisingly. I couldn't finish.Went on another occasion where I sat at the bar and had their whiskey sour with homemade almost syrup (can't remember the exact name) and was floored by how amazing it was. I requested the mac and cheese as well and it wasn't good at all. I will be back in the future for drinks and the bar vibe but wouldn't recommend for a special lunch or dinner.

jXHMYQEzdLWjCp08StpF5A.text: Nice venue, good food, ok service. The venue is cool-Brit pub-ish. Right on the Bay.  Both the burger and the shepherd's pie were really good (the burger slightly on the small side). Desserts looked interesting too... The service needs to improve (to start, the should pick up the phone, to take reservations).

9Uj8aERAx2dibpNGkF3hSQ.text: When they say they're fully booked and the restaurant looks half empty, they mean that the kitchen is slammed and can't serve you within whatever time limit they set for themselves.I've been to Bread Street Kitchen twice.  Both times have been good but not great.  Front of house is spoils it for me - they're terrible - but once you get past them, the actual service is really good.  The eats:Fish and Chips:  Hake, which I have never had before, fresh and perfectly prepared with a tasty batter,  good straight cut chips.  The tartare sauce was wonderful - with a hint of citrus which did a wonderful job of cutting the heaviness of the batter.  Mac & cheese: terrible - soft white cheese that tasted of nothing and little pools of oil.  The macaroni was a little mushy tooRoasted baby chicken with chimicurri sauce:  the chicken was done well though a little dry.  Lovely crispy golden skin.  The chimicurri sauce was oddly tasteless but they serve burnt lemon with this dish so I squeezed it on and it just made the chicken come alive - not literally because that would be scary - just made it taste better.  Seared scallops with carrot puree was so fishy I could not even eat a mouthful.  I paid for it but it really did not smell fresh.  Drinks: Suggest not to order off the menu if you're a cocktail purist.  I ordered a Expresso martini which they kindly said they would make it specially for me.  Oddly, they added milk and sugar syrup to it.  Perfectly drinkable but not quite right.Banana sticky toffee pudding, muscovado caramel, clotted cream:  COULD.NOT.STOP.EATINGTreacle tart with creme fraiche was outstanding - lovely warm treacle tart that wasn't too sweet.Eton mess - chef's special not on the ordinary menu - was a dessert cup of sinful goodness with vanilla cream, tiny crunchy meringues and a heavenly berry sauce.

mZAVGTVkSL_o-JQXNIPhZg.text: This is what a burger should taste like. I'm not sure it's the best but it's nice. The pork belly was nice as well although some pieces were a bit too hard. Maybe the cook is a closet arsonist. Loved the salmon ceviche as it's well balanced. The service is attentive and spot on(food served at the same time, refilling drinks, etc). Even the bread is nice as it's made in house. I think this place you'll need a reservation unless you come at an odd hour.

photos.caption: Photo of Bread Street Kitchen - Singapore, Singapore. Burger
Photo of Bread Street Kitchen - Singapore, Singapore. Salmon ceviche

8HEHhNP5TD-JUQoZWwEUgg.text: We came here for brunch on Sunday and the first thing that jumped out at me was the price of a cafe latte - $8.00. The coffee was the most expensive I've ever had & thankfully it was a great tasting coffee, up there with Melbourne coffee standards BUT when the coffee costs almost half the price of your main then that is a bit of a worry. I had the smoked salmon & scrambled eggs for main ($17) which was lovely except that my smoked salmon had a few bones in it and the toast came out with no butter. The staff are really lovely, attentive and professional. Overall the food is tasty, the service is really good and I would probably dine here again but I would ask that the price of the coffee is reviewed.

8ESBmbHt9y8hvhBAroFMMw.text: Definitely not what you would expect from Gordon Ramsey. The place is well decorated, good service, but the food and the menu are far from perfect. The hamburger is pretty normal, you can find much better burgers in any random place. The tuna tartar was supposed to be spicy, but not. And the fish and chips is ok, well fried. I don't think I will come again.

9p4hTbVVXjtzJh5jeB3bgg.text: I love the service its nice fast very good but about the food it is not very exceptional. The quality is not like michellan star like.

PawJE9UGrotigI2IyqP_jQ.text: I didn't really enjoy my experience here. Our waiter seemed arrogant and not very inviting. Bread basket was stale. Spring chicken, pork belly, mashed potatoes and onion rings were good but nothing to write home about. At the end of the meal I ordered an espresso with Bailey's and it was completely curdled. They did take it back and replace it, but chunky espresso makes for a gross experience. All in all, I just feel the ambiance and the food aren't really worth the prices.

KL-Et8kQrgp3sM_9oiULwQ.text: Delicious.The Beef Wellington is delicious.And the wait staff is so great. Highly recommend!

photos.caption: Photo of Bread Street Kitchen - Singapore, Singapore
Photo of Bread Street Kitchen - Singapore, Singapore
Photo of Bread Street Kitchen - Singapore, Singapore

7CQhe2AcpGqi9x7VF4B0lQ.text: The food here is good but is pretty pricey for what you get. I had a cocktail for 22 SGD and a hamburger for 29 SGD.  The burger and the cocktail were both good just over priced. My servers were friendly and attentive and I thought the service was quite good. My four star rating is based on:Food: 4 starsValue: 3 starsService/environment: 4 stars

GHf8jtX1MbJTusLMhnvI7w.text: I've been to Hell's Kitchen so I do think that Gordon Ramsay's food is pretty good. Alas, I also know that celebrity chef restaurants mean celebrity chef prices and that's what has dampened my enthusiasm somewhat. Still Bread Street Kitchen was decent, if not mind-blowing.We arrived at 1130am for brunch and were seated almost immediately, the restaurant was relatively full for pre-lunch hour and many people were celebrating birthdays. I guess it is a pretty nice place for a celebration.We shared the scallops as a starter - they were good though unremarkable and unfortunately very salty.For my main, I ordered the corn fritters. They arrived and looked quite beautiful except that they were definitely not fritters and more like pancakes. Still delicious with the sour cream, guac and sauteed peppers but I was a little disappointed because I was looking forward to some crisp fritters for lunch. I'd have been happier if they just changed the name to manage expectations.Someone at my table ordered the signature fish and chips - it was pretty well done and was a huge piece of fish! It was nicely fried, well battered and very fresh. I liked their little jars of ketchup and tartar sauce too.The highlight of the meal however, was the free jar of cookies that came with the check! Oatmeal chocolate chip cookies - fresh and crisp and not too sweet. I had to close the jar to stop myself from finishing them all.

photos.caption: Photo of Bread Street Kitchen - Singapore, Singapore. Oatmeal chocolate chip cookies
Photo of Bread Street Kitchen - Singapore, Singapore. Fish & chips
Photo of Bread Street Kitchen - Singapore, Singapore. Corn fritters

f3eRGUxl3cpo7CeAsov5_w.text: I only go for the fish n chips! Staff is friendly. The view of the promenade is not bad for a nice lunch :)

photos.caption: Photo of Bread Street Kitchen - Singapore, Singapore

6CugYLxatu7zvgXwvlvoqw.text: Food was mediocre as HELL!!Poor / slow service. Tried to dine downstairs the hostess sent us upstairs to bar. Once at bar that hostess tried to send us downstairs!? Finally we just asked to sit at bar which had room, but, needed to clean the space.. but.. at our suggestion! If we'd have been content to leave, they would've been just as happy not to be rushed or bothered!!

09qVGrPjxOArSJsNi9wesg.text: I was at the Gardens by the Bay for the Orchid Extravaganza Garden Trail this morning. I have bookmarked Gordon Ramsay's Bread Street Kitchen since last year but never get a chance to try it.Guess today was the day when I should go check it out. I had been to a Gordon Ramsay's Michelin-starred restaurant decade ago. It was a great memorable dining experience for me. Bread Street Kitchen was located at L1 at The Shoppes at Marina May Sands. I read somewhere it was supposed to be a casual restaurant but I do not recommend wearing shorts and flip flops here. There was only one thing I wanted to try for my first visit to Bread Street Kitchen. That would be the Classic Fish & Chips. FOODClassic Fish & Chips with crushed peas & tartar sauce - 4/5 ~ The portion was generous. The type of fish used here was lingcod. I guess I like my fish to be of Atlantic Cod. Anyhow, the batter was perfect. Love the chips, they were thicker than the normal American fries. The crushed peas was nasty.   Sorry, it looked like those pea purée for babies and I must say this must be one of those acquired taste kind of thing :PIced Lemon Tea - 5/5 ~ different in a very good way. Not too sweet and 100% refreshing!!AMBIENCE - 5/5I like the décor, music a tad loud for me. SERVICE -5/5Karen was very friendly and attentive. After the food was served, she came back and checked how I like the food. When I was done with the food (no, I couldn't finish all my food), she cleared the plate and cleaned up any crumbs on the table. Shortly after I asked for the check, she came back with an iPad and asked if I would be kind to give a survey of the dining experience today. How could I say no when someone asked so nicely? :D She also left a jar of chocolate chip cookies with a tong. I took one out to try, it was very good! Crisp and not too sugary sweet. I was planning to give an overall 4 star for my review but Karen was so outstanding (hard to get such service these days) and so I am happy to award a 5 stars to Bread Street Kitchen. I hope Gordon Ramsay will give her a raise or promotion, lol!

photos.caption: Photo of Bread Street Kitchen - Singapore, Singapore. View from where I sit
Photo of Bread Street Kitchen - Singapore, Singapore. Complimentary chocolate chip cookies (please only take one! Lol!)
Photo of Bread Street Kitchen - Singapore, Singapore. Iced lemon tea

Qg2EZra4Vc9dVZORbVa8bA.text: If this is really Gordon's restaurant, Gordon would have given them bloody hell! Customer service is the worst! No one in there wants to do their job. We walked in and was seated. But had to ask for water 3 times. We ordered appetizers and the waiter never came back to take our order. The appetizers were mediocre. We finished our appetizer and asked for our check. We paid and left with a complaint to the manager.

photos.caption: Photo of Bread Street Kitchen - Singapore, Singapore
Photo of Bread Street Kitchen - Singapore, Singapore

K9DqOEzDkYlgOHfhxpbr5Q.text: Place was great. Price is correct for a good meal in Singapore. I will recommend this place to friends

fULBljKGYR9mGu0Z5kPekA.text: Had breakfast at Gordon Ramsay's Bread Street Kitchen. Thoroughly enjoyed my English breakfast by the bay.

photos.caption: Photo of Bread Street Kitchen - Singapore, Singapore
Photo of Bread Street Kitchen - Singapore, Singapore
Photo of Bread Street Kitchen - Singapore, Singapore

H4feBiMx4VpfxvdWhNOpuQ.text: Sorry but I ate the pictures before taking them... Decided to try Gordon Ramsey's food and recipes to see how they turnout. Started with two appetizers, the tamarind spiced chicken wings and the tuna tartar with crispy wantons. First the wings. They were probably the worst wings I have ever encountered. It had a hard breaded shell with an overly sweet (no hint of the tamarind) sauce. The colder the wings got the tougher they became. Second the tuna tartar. The tuna was almost flavorless except for some sesame oil which is fairly mild. The crispy wonton skins made up for the dish.For the entree, my dining partner and I decided to try the roasted pork belly with an apple chutney/roulade. The pork had the skin left on and it was roasted into a hard crust. Furthermore the crust was quite heavily salted that it made it difficult to. It sat in a soy sauce based sauce which made it saltier and difficult to cut into even with a steak knife. The saving grace was the pork itself was cooked perfectly and was not too fatty as pork belly can tend to be. The apple chutney was excellent and went well with the pork meat.Service was very good and the servers were more than attentive. The bread bowl came out quickly and so did our waters. Even though the bottle of water sat onour table. The servers would refill our glasses periodically.The bottom line is that I am not sure if I will make an effort to visit here again.

Ss7fN617CFcxY_6JtlOpgw.text: Gordon Ramsay has never let me down!  Took a party of 6 there. Clients. Service was top notch. They are very diligent and making sure you are always taking care of. Well worth the dollars spent. Food was top notch. Some great classics and of course - the steak was awesome.   Conveniently located, casual but elegant feel. Can't recommend it enough. Save room for dessert. I'm not a huge dessert fan but the choices were hard to turn down.

fbxn-DPf7etcATczaoOuyg.text: I couldn't fault anything service level was over the top. The food was amazing perfect steak and also the fish and chips was the best I have ever had. And a great surprise was my favourite australian boutique beer fat yak. I will defiantly return. Advise it's best to make a booking but even if you haven't the staff will find somewhere for you to sit. I was also expecting it to be much more expensive the price was right.

photos.caption: Photo of Bread Street Kitchen - Singapore, Singapore

A0n2-eZjvjhIaiAPN4vyDA.text: The BSK concept is very simple: well-executed familiar dishes prepared with good-quality ingredients, then use the brand name to charge (super) premium pricing. Service is friendly and competent by a well-trained staff. The wine list has some good selections. Nothing to complain about if prices are not an issue (like if you're loaded or when you come as someone's guest); otherwise, I would prefer to go to a place with more innovative dishes, even if I had to pay a bit more. Ironically, the bread is definitely not memorable! ;)

photos.caption: Photo of Bread Street Kitchen - Singapore, Singapore
Photo of Bread Street Kitchen - Singapore, Singapore
Photo of Bread Street Kitchen - Singapore, Singapore

z_4MXsI8j8yZUHdhoh3-YA.text: exceptional food and gluten free options including gluten free bread. We had angus tip and roast veg. Top notch meal, top notch service.

KmuMzjFxlnac7kAEFuPzcg.text: More Than Just Comfort Food In This Kitchen. All I can say is...... Finally!!After months and months of debating if I should give Bread Street Kitchen a shot, we decided to make our way down to finally give it a try. I have to admit, I'm a huge.... HUGE fan of Gordon Ramsey's, so I was caught on the fence about the initial reviews. Having eaten at Gordon Ramsey at the London in Manhattan (now closed) and his flag ship restaurant Gordon Ramsey at Hospital Road, in London, the expectations were pretty high. Yes, it's a casual take on Gordon Ramsey and yes it's comfort food but..... It's still a Gordon Ramsey group of restaurants. So while a part of me said YES I have to eat here, the other half told me "but what if it's a let down like initial reviews suggested?".Initial Service. Was a little disappointed. Considering how you get immediate attention and service and his other restaurant, this one was a little slower. No hostess at the reception counter, wait staff and managers glancing over with no one really saying anything u till the hostess arrived a minute or so later. However, hostess was polite enough to explain that the restaurant was fully reserved and that we had to return our table in an hour. No harm darn considering a) this wasn't a fine dining 3 hour long lunch experience b) we had to get back to the museum for some workshops anyway.The Menu Nothing overly elaborate. 3 page menu filled with comfort food ranging from a Brunch items like Eggs Benedict to Salads, hot mains and Grilled items like Roasted Chicken and Angus steaks. The Price I have to admit, a little of the steep side. Having lunched at his other 2 restaurants, which offered 3 course lunch specials for £35 and USD45, a S$38 Shepherd's pie is a bit pricey. However, considering that this IS Marina Bay Sands where you pay $10 for chicken rice and $27 for a Margherita pizza. We decided to go with the basics. After all, isn't the simplest food the hardest to prepare?Bread Basket The break selection is fantastic! And the butter? To die for! My only wish was that the bread was a little warmer but the variety given was fantastic and tasted great. Couldn't have asked for more. Scallops Off the bat, perfectly cooked scallops. Having had below par scallops recently, this certainly helped the Gf put into perspective what beautifully cooked scallops should taste like. The carrot purée though, I thought, was a little light. While smooth and still a bit sweet, it didn't quite shine like a carrot purée should, with the purée offering more texture than it does flavour. The apple and bacon combination was delightful though, offering enough saltiness, with the richness cut by the apples. However, while the sweetness of the scallops was this there, eating it without the purée and apples made it a bit on the salty side. Overall, still a good dish and nothing is more comforting that the holy trinity of Scallop, Bacon and Apples. Fish & Chips Now THIS is what I call fish and chips. Unfortunately, a lot of the fish and chips in Singapore, though claiming to be authentic British fish and chips, some how still feels a bit of a let down.From the first cut, you would know that this is a good Fish and Chips. The batter was thin and crispy and a first cut in reveals a very juicy, perfectly cooked piece of cod. Juicy, succulent. Although not as large as Smith's, the difference in quality is undeniable. The fish was fresh, not frozen and it was beautifully seasoned. And the chips. The chips are so so so good! By far one of the best fish and chips I've had in Singapore. Millionaires Shortbread with Hazel-Nut milk Sorbet. Chocolate lovers rejoice! This is definitely an ultimate chocolate lover's delight! Rich and smooth chocolate on top with a brownie like base, this is what I call A DESSERT!The hazel-nut milk sorbet was more ice cream than sorbet and was rather sweet but it's creaminess did add to the smoothness of an already rich chocolate "cake".   Overall impression. While the food was good, service was average. While staff were friendly, it did feel like they were a bit stretched, with the chef calling service please 3-4 times before dessert was picked up and the bill taking a fair bit to reach us. Will we be back? Definitely. If they could make fish and chips that good, I can't wait to try the rest of their dishes. However, because of the price, I can see why people are put off. Blame it on rental or the fact that he's a celebrity chef in MBS but the restaurant would have gotten a solid 5 had it not been for the slow service and price.

photos.caption: Photo of Bread Street Kitchen - Singapore, Singapore
Photo of Bread Street Kitchen - Singapore, Singapore
Photo of Bread Street Kitchen - Singapore, Singapore

O2OvbPCaJi2Z1RK0j_KMHQ.text: We had an early dinner here after visiting the ArtScience Museum at the other end of Marina Bay Shoppes.I enjoyed the bread basket and my main of grilled lamb. My husband got a salad and liked everything about it - freshness, texture, presentation.All in all, a great experience. Planning our return visit the next time we are in Singapore.

72wgPoCmUo4W99g81Qx2Uw.text: Ah, celebrity chefs. Love them, or hate them. We, in Singapore are always very fortunate to have world renowned chefs opening their establishments here giving us an opportunity to try their creation in our home soil rather than flying halfway across the globe. From Wolfgang Puck to Tetsuya Wakuda to Joel Robouchon - we have it all here. And just recently Gordon Ramsay, the no-nonsense chef we love watching on TV opened his first restaurant in MBS and got everyone excited. I called two days ago and was told the restaurant is fully booked everyday until July 28th. Two days ago was July 1st. Not giving up, my friend and I walked in at 6pm yesterday with "puss-in-boots" lost and hungry expression while pushing our luck with the hostess in charge. Turns out she has a table and the reservation is only by 730pm. She asked if we can finish by then and we happily said FOR SHUREEEE! We have the best table for the night, on the lower floor, quieter and right next to the open kitchen. Upon seated, we were presented with a basket of various home-made bread served with a slab of salted butter. We then proceed to order one item from each category - from cold starter, to hot starter to mains. First off - Alaskan king crab and apple cocktail with pink peppercorn. Delicious. Succulent and plump pieces of Alaskan king crab tossed with thin apple slices in light dressing. A refreshing start to a great meal. Next up, we have English green asparagus with parma ham, poached egg and hollandaise sauce. The parma ham could be more generous in my opinion since they charge $20 for 4 stalks of pathetic looking asparagus. Taste wise, it was pretty good with a combination of different textures from the asparagus, the smoothness of the poached egg and hollandaise sauce. For salad, we ordered warm bang bang chicken salad with watercress mouli, chili, beansprout, radish, ginger and peanuts. So good! Nothing beats a warm salad with pieces of chicken that pack a punch. The chili woke up the taste buds (and sweat glands too) and I did break a sweat or two while polishing the dish clean. All the mains sound good from the menu and we were torn between BSK short rib burger or the slow roasted pork belly, but alas, our host won us over by suggesting the traditional fish and chips with crushed peas and tartar sauce - a British classic and an all-time favorite. The fish and chips is decent and live up to expectations. Lightly battered while maintaining the freshness of the fish after deep frying. I wish they serve 2 pieces of fillet instead of one though. What impress me most is the mustard and ketchup in a jar so cute you want to steal it home (but please don't, stay classy!) from Wilkin & Sons Ltd. So very Bri-ish Stamford Raffles would be so proud. Overall, it was an enjoyable evening - food is great and service is commendable. Maybe it's still early and the restaurant wasn't that pack so we get all the attention. It was my first experience eating at Ramsay's restaurant and I came with no expectation. And usually when you have the least expectations, it will surpass and impress. Some of you might argue you have better experience from his restaurants elsewhere, but for me, the restaurant deserves a 3.72957 stars, round up to 4. Definitely coming back in the next couple of months and see how it matures.  p/s: 3 appetizers, 1 main, 1 glass of house red + 1  beer = $136 without tax.

I3MOhJMS9CElvZ29se-YWw.text: Had the pleasure to eat both a dinner and brunch at BSK this past week.  First, I was surprised at the reasonable pricing, thought a signature chef restaurant would be more pricey.  The dinner was on my own and at the servers suggestion, I had the chicken caesar and mac and cheese.  Both were great and good combination.  Liked the boiled egg in the salad.  Then went back to brunch with my wife.  I had the open-faced omelette and it was outstanding, she had the eggs benedict with spinach, which was also good, but the omelette was better.The service was also excellent.  We didn't have a reservation, which I'd advise, but they still accommodated us on the upper level with view.  Our server was also very attentive.Definitely will go back again next time I'm in the MBS area.

xmtVgMb9-IhhiGJEzBCtew.text: Came here on a Monday night as my friend and I were in the area. And since she talked about Chef Gordon Ramsay, I decided to bring her here to give it a try.While entering the open concept restaurant, we were greeted by a female staff and she asked us whether we had any reservation. As we did not have one, we were asked whether we mind bar seats. Without much hesitation, we said we do not mind. We were led to our high chair seatings (facing each other). I decided to sit facing the waters. Took a quick look at the menu and ordered the following.1) Fish & Chips - The beer battered fish fillet was great. It was slightly fried giving the top part a crispy touch to it. The thick cut fries was disappointing though as it has not much taste to it. I had to ask the waiter whether there is mashed potato gravy and he ended up getting me their special brown sauce (a few ingredients mixed and similar to bbq sauce but it had a tangy taste). The crushed peas was interesting and the tartar sauce was great if eaten with the fish fillet. Unfortunately this dish did not live up to my expectations especially after staying in Sydney for 4 months.2) Onion rings - 6 rings inside a bowl. The flour overpowered the taste of the onions. It was crunchy but would prefer to be served warmer. This appetizer is really filling and even without condiments, it is salty. 3) Pineapple Carpaccio, passionfruit and coconut sorbet - I ordered this as it has all my favorite tropical fruits in a dish. When the dish arrived, I was wow-ed by the looks. The grated coconut flakes and the thinly sliced pineapples were pretty attractive on a white serving plate. The coconut sorbet was also perfectly scooped. This dish did impressed me. The thinly sliced pineapple that looks like flower petals were sweet. And with the addition of scattered passionfruit with seeds it made the dish to be both sweet and sour. And the coconut flakes added the crunch to the dish. The coconut sorbet was not too sweet either. Definitely love this plate of dessert.4) Rhythm & Blues (mocktail/ non-alcoholic) - somehow the ingredients inside this beverage made me order this beverage. It came in a martini glass. The mocktail was fruity and refreshing. And there was a mint leaf on top of it too to add flavor to the drink. At the top of the beverage, there was a foamy layer and the bartender added salt and pepper. You could taste the interesting spun for this drink towards the end and yes, it was addictive. This drink has less ice too so it was not diluted.5) Forbidden forest (mocktail/ non-alcoholic) - this drink came in a tall glass with a small base. It came with a straw and you could see the crushed ice too. On top of the drink, there was a raspberry and a small touch of rosemary. Unfortunately this drink was a little diluted (too much ice) and you could probably finish it in countable sips. Before the dishes and the beverages arrive, we were given freshly baked homemade breads. The breads were alright but the butter that accompanied the bread was addictive. It melts inside the mouth and was not as salty as I had expected. Service here was pretty efficient. Once you raise your hand up in the air, a waiter or waitress will head to you quickly. I would prefer my dishes to be warmer and the price to be lower. Good experience dining in a restaurant opened by a celebrity chef.

photos.caption: Photo of Bread Street Kitchen - Singapore, Singapore
Photo of Bread Street Kitchen - Singapore, Singapore
Photo of Bread Street Kitchen - Singapore, Singapore

KK4TRbMm-qDQpFKl332wbg.text: Celebrity chefs. Its easy to sell the concept especially in a very brand conscious city like Singapore. Furthermore, it location - Marina Bay Sands - thrives on this concept. You name the luxury brand, we have it there. A fan of GR himself, I may prove to be a tad bias on this review. In addition, i must add that I went with my mom and her group of friends. So, in essence, my experience wasn't the most refined but relatable to the heartlander.At least the wait staff was patient enough to handle the aunty-ness in my mom and her friends. Allowing them to randomly call out items from the menu and turning a blind eye to the concept of them sharing everything they ordered. They were also proactive to offer suggestions on what to order based on the clientele of the table, which I appreciated.For starters, the corn soup was amazing. The texture and the protein was well done. Creamy and flavourful. A very good way to start the meal. Their asian flavoured wings (9 pieces in all) were well marinated and had a tang to it. My mom's friends call it the atas har cheong kai (upscale spiced chicken wing) and enjoyed relishing its taste with their fingers while I quietly attempt not to cringe.For the mains, they ordered the smoked salmon and the sunday special, Sunday Roast. While I had the rib eye which was not exactly done as per ordered - medium rare - but overall the flavour was there. The bernaise sauce that accompanied the steak was good. Overall, all the mains we ordered met expectations and the portions just right.As for dessert, i was floored with their chocolate cake with mint ice cream. My two favourite flavours in the entire world. It was as if this dessert was made just for me. The center was oozing with chocolatey goodness and the mint ice cream was just smooth and not too sweet. Oh and the aunties ordered a berry pie, which was okay. Tartness was there but compared to me cake... Let's just say it wasnt the best. Haha.I would come back here again to get a taste of their other dishes. Although i must admit with a table of 5 we covered about 25% of the items off the menu. The aunties love it and they will be back with more aunty-ness with their family and othee aunty friends. So I guess GR can't go very wrong with this joint. Maybe next time I'll come with a more sophisticated crowd to see how its like on the other side of the grass patch. Till then, enjoy BSK!
